pages.name: Qualifying Questions

elements.name: explanationQualifying
elements.title:
This service will help you apply for a Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`.

There is more than one kind of `order` that can protect you and your family. The following questions will help you decide if a `protection order` under the Family Law Act of British Columbia is right for you.

elements.name: unsafe
elements.title: Is someone making you (or your family) feel `unsafe`?

elements.name: explanationUnsafe
elements.title: It seems you do not need this service.

elements.name: unsafePartner
elements.title: Was (or is) this person your partner?
elements.description:
A partner can include someone:
  • you were (or are) married to, or
  • you lived (or live) with in a marriage-like relationship, or
  • you have a child with

elements.name: faqUnsafePartner1
elements.title: Does my ex-boyfriend or ex-girlfriend count as my partner?
elements.body:
If they lived (or live) with you in a marriage-like relationship for any period of time then, yes, they count as your partner. Also, if the two of you have a child together then, yes, they count as your partner.

If they did not live with you in a marriage-like relationship or have children with you, they do not count as a partner for the purpose of this service.

elements.name: explanationUnsafePartnerNo
elements.title:
This service cannot help you.

For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. This service can only be used to apply for a Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order` against someone who was (or is) your partner.

If a `family member` that is not your (ex-)partner is making you feel `unsafe`, you can still apply for Provincial Court Family Law Act Protection Order.

Click here for Provincial Court Family Forms. (This link will open in a new tab.)

If someone that is not a `family member` (including someone you have only dated, such as an ex-boyfriend/ex-girlfriend) is making you feel unsafe, you can still apply for an order to protect you. This order is called a `Peace Bond`. This service cannot be used to get a Peace Bond. If you think you need a Peace Bond, contact the police or RCMP for assistance.

For additional support, call VictimLink BC 1-800-563-0808 (no charge), 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

elements.name: eitherHaveChildren
elements.title: Do either of you have children?

elements.name: childrenHaveOtherGuardians
elements.title: Do any of these children have parents or `legal guardians` other than you and your (ex-)partner?

elements.name: explanationChildrenHaveOtherGuardiansYes
elements.title:
This service cannot help you.

For now, this service has only been developed for a limited number of situations. This service is currently limited to situations where (ex-)partners have shared children. These children cannot have parents or guardians other than you and your (ex-)partner.

If any children have parents or guardians other than you and your (ex-)partner, you can still apply for Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`.

Click here for Provincial Court Family Forms. (This link will open in a new tab.)

For additional support, call VictimLink BC 1-800-563-0808 (no charge), 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

elements.name: existingPOR
elements.title: Do you already have a `Family Law Act Protection Order` that protects you from the (ex-)partner who is making you feel unsafe?

elements.name: faqExistingPOR1
elements.title: What if I have a `Peace Bond` that protects me from the (ex-)partner who is making me feel unsafe?
elements.body:
A `Peace Bond` is not a `Family Law Act Protection Order`.

A `Peace Bond` is another kind of `Protection Order` that covers more situations. You may apply for both a Family law Act Protection Order and a Peace Bond at the same time.

You will asked to include a copy of your Peace Bond.

elements.name: faqExistingPOR2
elements.title: What if there is a No-Contact order that protects me from the (ex-)partner who is making me feel unsafe?
elements.body:
A No-Contact Order is not a `Family Law Act Protection Order`.

A No-Contact Order is a part of your (ex-)partner's criminal matter that can protect you (and your family). When your (ex-)partner's criminal matter is finished, the No-Contact Order may not be in effect anymore.

elements.name: existingPORBC
elements.title: Was this `Family Law Act Protection Order` made from a court in British Columbia?

elements.name: existingPORBCCourt
elements.title: Was this `Family Law Act Protection Order` made in the Provincial Court of British Columbia or the Supreme Court of British Columbia?

elements.name: explanationExistingPORBCNo
elements.title:
Depending on where your original `Protection Order` was made, it may or may not be enforceable in British Columbia.

You can use this service to apply for a new `Family Law Act Protection Order` from the Provincial Court of British Columbia. You will asked to include a copy of your original Protection Order.

elements.name: existingPORBCProvincialExpired
elements.title: Has this Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order` expired?

elements.name: explanationExistingPORBCProvincialExpiredYes
elements.title:
You can use this service to apply for a new Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`.

You will asked to include a copy of your original Protection Order.

elements.name: explanationExistingPORBCProvincialExpiredNo
elements.title:
This service cannot help you.

If you need to change a condition or change the expiry date on your Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`, there is a different form to complete. You can copy most of the information from the original forms you used to apply for your original Protection Order.

Click here to download the form you need. (This link will open in a new tab.)

For additional support, call VictimLink BC 1-800-563-0808 (no charge), 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

elements.name: existingPORBCSupremeExpired
elements.title: Has this Supreme Court `Family Law Act Protection Order` expired?

elements.name: explanationExistingPORBCSupremeExpiredYes
elements.title:
This service cannot help you apply for a new Supreme Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`.

If you want to apply for a new Supreme Court Family Law Act Protection Order, there is a different form to complete. You may be able to copy most of the information from the original forms you used to apply for your original Protection Order. There are fees for applying in Supreme Court. You can apply to waive the fee if you meet certain financial criteria.

Click here for Supreme Court Family Forms. (This link will open in a new tab.)

Because your previous Supreme Court Family Law Act Protection Order has expired and is no longer in effect, you can choose to apply for a new Family Law Act Protection Order in the Provincial Court. There are no fees to apply in Provincial Court.

If you want to apply for a Provincial Court Family Law Act Protection Order instead, press ‘Continue’ below.

elements.name: explanationExistingPORBCSupremeExpiredNo
elements.title:
This service cannot help you.

Because you already have a Supreme Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`, and that order has not expired, you will need to return to the Supreme Court if you want to make any changes.

If you need to add a condition, change a condition or change the expiry date on your on your Supreme Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`, there is a different form to complete. You may be able to copy most of the information from the original forms you used to apply for your existing Protection Order.

Click here for Supreme Court Family Forms. (This link will open in a new tab.)

elements.name: confirmPanel
PORConfirmed
elements.title: You appear to meet the requirements to use this service to apply for a Provincial Court `Family Law Act Protection Order`. Confirm that this is what you want to do.
elements.description:
You may also want to consider applying for a `Peace Bond`. A Peace Bond is another kind of `Protection Order` that covers more situations. You may apply for both a Family law Act Protection Order and a Peace Bond at the same time.

Family Law Act Protection Order Peace Bond
To apply for a Family Law Act Protection Order, you will need to tell your story directly to a judge. You can apply on your own or you can hire a lawyer to help. If a judge decides that your situation is urgent, they may hear your application the same day you file it, without your (ex-)partner needing to be in court. To get a Peace Bond, you will need to tell your story to the police, who may then decide to tell your story to Crown Counsel, who may then decide if a judge is likely to make your Protection Order. Your (ex-)partner will have an opportunity to tell their story. You may be called as witness.


Click here for more information about the differences between a Peace Bond and a Provincial Court Family Law Act Protection Order. (This link will open in a new tab.)
